1.text: “I have made a covenant with my eyes. How then could I gaze with desire at a virgin?

2.text: For what is the allotment of God from above, or the heritage from the Almighty on high?

3.text: Does not disaster come to the unjust and calamity to the workers of iniquity?

4.text: Does He not see my ways and count my every step?

5.text: If I have walked in falsehood or my foot has rushed to deceit,

6.text: let God weigh me with honest scales, that He may know my integrity.

7.text: If my steps have turned from the path, if my heart has followed my eyes, or if impurity has stuck to my hands,

8.text: then may another eat what I have sown, and may my crops be uprooted.

9.text: If my heart has been enticed by my neighbor’s wife, or I have lurked at his door,

10.text: then may my own wife grind grain for another, and may other men sleep with her.

11.text: For that would be a heinous crime, an iniquity to be judged.

12.text: For it is a fire that burns down to Abaddon; it would root out my entire harvest.

13.text: If I have rejected the cause of my manservant or maidservant when they made a complaint against me,

14.text: what will I do when God rises to judge? How will I answer when called to account?

15.text: Did not He who made me in the womb also make them? Did not the same One form us in the womb?

16.text: If I have denied the desires of the poor or allowed the widow’s eyes to fail,

17.text: if I have eaten my morsel alone, not sharing it with the fatherless—

18.text: though from my youth I reared him as would a father, and from my mother’s womb I guided the widow—

19.text: if I have seen one perish for lack of clothing, or a needy man without a cloak,

20.text: if his heart has not blessed me for warming him with the fleece of my sheep,

21.text: if I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless because I saw that I had support in the gate,

22.text: then may my arm fall from my shoulder and be torn from its socket.

23.text: For calamity from God terrifies me, and His splendor I cannot overpower.

24.text: If I have put my trust in gold or called pure gold my security,

25.text: if I have rejoiced in my great wealth because my hand had gained so much,

26.text: if I have beheld the sun in its radiance or the moon moving in splendor,

27.text: so that my heart was secretly enticed and my hand threw a kiss from my mouth,

28.text: this would also be an iniquity to be judged, for I would have denied God on high.

29.text: If I have rejoiced in my enemy’s ruin, or exulted when evil befell him—

30.text: I have not allowed my mouth to sin by asking for his life with a curse—

31.text: if the men of my house have not said, ‘Who is there who has not had his fill?’—

32.text: but no stranger had to lodge on the street, for my door has been open to the traveler—

33.text: if I have covered my transgressions like Adam by hiding my guilt in my heart,

34.text: because I greatly feared the crowds and the contempt of the clans terrified me, so that I kept silent and would not go outside—

35.text: (Oh, that I had one to hear me! Here is my signature. Let the Almighty answer me; let my accuser compose an indictment.

36.text: Surely I would carry it on my shoulder and wear it like a crown.

37.text: I would give account of all my steps; I would approach Him like a prince.)—

38.text: if my land cries out against me and its furrows weep together,

39.text: if I have devoured its produce without payment or broken the spirit of its tenants,

40.text: then let briers grow instead of wheat and stinkweed instead of barley.” Thus conclude the words of Job.
